Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Surgical Ablation for Atrial Fibrillation

Participants.evidence: patients with symptomatic AF unresponsive to antiarrhythmic drugs or catheter ablation. Conducted in Brazil

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to undergo the Cox-Maze IV procedure with LAA occlusion or receive standard medical therapy

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the effectiveness of the Cox-Maze IV procedure combined with left atrial appendage (LAA) occlusion in treating AF

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was freedom from AF at 12 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: 98 participants were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach, while 97 were analysed in the control group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group achieved a 92% AF freedom rate at 12 months, significantly higher than the 0% in the control group (p < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events in the intervention group included renal dysfunction and pacemaker requirement in <5% of patients

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by Brazilian Ministry of Health
